statements.name: PROC FACTOR
statements.description: The FACTOR procedure performs a variety of common factor and component analyses and rotations. Input can be multivariate data, a correlation matrix, a covariance matrix, a factor pattern, or a matrix of scoring coefficients. The procedure can factor either the correlation or covariance matrix, and you can save most results in an output data set.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Displays all optional output except plots. When the input data set is TYPE=CORR, TYPE=UCORR, TYPE=COV, TYPE=UCOV, or TYPE=FACTOR, simple statistics, correlations, and MSA are not displayed.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Specifies the level of confidence 1 - α for interval construction. By default, α= 0.05, corresponding to 1 - α= 95% confidence intervals.

arguments.name: CONVERGE=
arguments.description: Specifies the convergence criterion for the METHOD=PRINIT, METHOD=ULS, METHOD=ALPHA, or METHOD=ML option.

arguments.name: CORR
arguments.description: Displays the correlation matrix or partial correlation matrix.

arguments.name: COVARIANCE
arguments.description: Requests factoring of the covariance matrix instead of the correlation matrix. The COV option is effective only with the METHOD=PRINCIPAL, METHOD=PRINIT, METHOD=ULS, or METHOD=IMAGE option.

arguments.name: COVER
arguments.description: Computes the confidence intervals and optionally specifies the value of factor loading for coverage detection. By default, p = 0.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the input data set, which can be an ordinary SAS data set or a specially structured SAS data set. If the DATA= option is omitted, the most recently created SAS data set is used.

arguments.name: EIGENVECTORS
arguments.description: Displays the eigenvectors of the reduced correlation matrix, of which the diagonal elements are replaced with the communality estimates.

arguments.name: FLAG=
arguments.description: Flags absolute values larger than p with an asterisk in the correlation and loading matrices.

arguments.name: FUZZ=
arguments.description: Prints correlations and factor loadings with absolute values less than p printed as missing.

arguments.name: GAMMA=
arguments.description: Specifies the orthomax weight used with the option ROTATE=ORTHOMAX or PREROTATE=ORTHOMAX.

arguments.name: HEYWOOD
arguments.description: Sets to 1 any communality greater than 1, allowing iterations to proceed.

arguments.name: HKPOWER=
arguments.description: Specifies the power of the square roots of the eigenvalues used to rescale the eigenvectors for Harris-Kaiser (ROTATE=HK) rotation, assuming that the factors are extracted by the principal factor method.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of iterations for factor extraction.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the method for extracting factors. The default is METHOD=PRINCIPAL unless the DATA= data set is TYPE=FACTOR, in which case the default is METHOD=PATTERN.
arguments.help: METHOD=ALPHA|A | HARRIS|H | IMAGE|I | ML|M | PATTERN | PRINCIPAL|PRIN|P | PRINIT | SCORE | ULS|U

arguments.name: ALPHA
arguments.description: Produces α factor analysis.

arguments.name: HARRIS
arguments.description: Yields Harris component analysis, a noniterative approximation to canonical component analysis.

arguments.name: IMAGE
arguments.description: Yields principal component analysis of the image covariance matrix, not Kaiser’s or Kaiser and Rice’s image analysis.

arguments.name: ML
arguments.description: Performs maximum likelihood factor analysis.

arguments.name: PATTERN
arguments.description: Reads a factor pattern from a TYPE=FACTOR, TYPE=CORR, TYPE=UCORR, TYPE=COV, or TYPE=UCOV data set.

arguments.name: PRINCIPAL
arguments.description: Yields principal component analysis if no PRIORS option or statement is used or if you specify PRIORS=ONE

arguments.name: PRINIT
arguments.description: Yields iterated principal factor analysis.

arguments.name: SCORE
arguments.description: Reads scoring coefficients (_TYPE_=’SCORE’) from a TYPE=FACTOR, TYPE=CORR, TYPE=UCORR, TYPE=COV, or TYPE=UCOV data set.

arguments.name: ULS
arguments.description: Produces unweighted least squares factor analysis.

arguments.name: MINEIGEN=
arguments.description: Specifies the smallest eigenvalue for which a factor is retained.

arguments.name: MSA
arguments.description: Produces the partial correlations between each pair of variables controlling for all other variables (the negative anti-image correlations) and Kaiser’s measure of sampling adequacy.

arguments.name: NFACTORS=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of factors to be extracted and determines the amount of memory to be allocated for factor matrices.

arguments.name: NOBS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of observations. If the DATA= input data set is a raw data set, nobs is defined by default to be the number of observations in the raw data set.

arguments.name: NOCORR
arguments.description: Prevents the correlation matrix from being transferred to the OUTSTAT= data set when you specify the METHOD=PATTERN option.

arguments.name: NOINT
arguments.description: Omits the intercept from the analysis; covariances or correlations are not corrected for the mean.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the display of all output. Note that this option temporarily disables the Output Delivery System (ODS).

arguments.name: NOPROMAXNORM
arguments.description: Turns off the default row normalization of the prerotated factor pattern, which is used in computing the promax target matrix.

arguments.name: NORM=
arguments.description: Specifies the method for normalizing the rows of the factor pattern for rotation.

arguments.name: COV
arguments.description: The rows of the pattern matrix are rescaled to represent covariances instead of correlations.

arguments.name: KAISER
arguments.description: Uses Kaiser’s normalization. This is the default.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Normalization is not performed.

arguments.name: RAW
arguments.description: Normalization is not performed.

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: The rows are weighted by the Cureton-Mulaik technique.

arguments.name: NPLOTS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of factors to be plotted. The default is to plot all factors. The smallest allowable value is 2.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Creates a data set containing all the data from the DATA= data set plus variables called Factor1, Factor2, and so on, containing estimated factor scores.

arguments.name: OUTSTAT=
arguments.description: Specifies an output data set containing most of the results of the analysis.

arguments.name: PARPREFIX=
arguments.description: Specifies the prefix for the residual variables in the OUT= and the OUTSTAT= data sets when partial variables are specified in the PARTIAL statement.

arguments.name: PLOT
arguments.description: Plots the factor pattern after rotation. This option produces printer plots. High-quality ODS graphical plots for factor patterns can be requested with the PLOTS=LOADINGS or PLOTS=INITLOADINGS option.

arguments.name: PLOTREF
arguments.description: Plots the reference structure instead of the default factor pattern after oblique rotation.

arguments.name: PLOTS=
arguments.description: Specifies one or more ODS graphical plots in PROC FACTOR. Syntax: (1) PLOTS <(global-plot-options)> = plot-request <(options)> | (2) PLOTS <(global-plot-options)> = (plot-request <(options)> <...plot-request <(options)> > ) The following are the available global-plot-options or options for plots: CIRCLE | CIRCLES < = numbers > specifies circles with prescribed areas to be drawn in scatter plots or vector plots, where the optional numbers represent proportions or percentages of areas enclosed by the circles in the plots. These numbers must lie between 0 and 100, inclusively. FLIP switches the X and Y axes. It applies to the INITLOADINGS, LOADINGS, and PRELOADINGS plot-requests. PLOTREF plots the reference structures rather than the factor pattern loadings. It applies to the INITLOADINGS, LOADINGS, and PRELOADINGS plot-requests when the factor solution is oblique. UNPACK plots component graphs separately. It applies to the SCREE plot-request only.
arguments.help: PLOTS=ALL | INITLOADINGS | LOADINGS | NONE | PRELOADINGS | SCREE

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: All available plots

arguments.name: INITLOADINGS
arguments.description: Unrotated factor loadings

arguments.name: LOADINGS
arguments.description: Rotated factor loadings

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No ODS graphical plots

arguments.name: PRELOADINGS
arguments.description: Prerotated factor loadings

arguments.name: SCREE
arguments.description: Scree and variance explained

arguments.name: POWER=
arguments.description: Specifies the power to be used in computing the target pattern for the option ROTATE=PROMAX. Valid values must be integers . The default value is 3.

arguments.name: PREFIX=
arguments.description: Specifies a prefix for naming the factors. By default, the names are Factor1, Factor2, ..., Factorn.

arguments.name: PREPLOT
arguments.description: Plots the factor pattern before rotation. This option produces printer plots. High-quality ODS graphical plots for factor patterns can be requested with the PLOTS=PRELOADINGS option.

arguments.name: PREROTATE=
arguments.description: Specifies the prerotation method for the option ROTATE=PROMAX.

arguments.name: PRINT
arguments.description: Displays the input factor pattern or scoring coefficients and related statistics. In oblique cases, the reference and factor structures are computed and displayed. The PRINT option is effective only with the option METHOD=PATTERN or METHOD=SCORE.

arguments.name: PRIORS=
arguments.description: Specifies a method for computing prior communality estimates.
arguments.help: PRIORS=ASMC|A | INPUT|I | MAX|M | ONE|O | RANDOM|R | SMC|S

arguments.name: ASMC
arguments.description: Sets the prior communality estimates proportional to the squared multiple correlations but adjusted so that their sum is equal to that of the maximum absolute correlations.

arguments.name: INPUT
arguments.description: Reads the prior communality estimates from the first observation with either _TYPE_=’PRIORS’ or _TYPE_=’COMMUNAL’ in the DATA= data set (which cannot be TYPE=DATA).

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: Sets the prior communality estimate for each variable to its maximum absolute correlation with any other variable.

arguments.name: ONE
arguments.description: Sets all prior communalities to 1.0.

arguments.name: RANDOM
arguments.description: Sets the prior communality estimates to pseudo-random numbers uniformly distributed between 0 and 1.

arguments.name: SMC
arguments.description: Sets the prior communality estimate for each variable to its squared multiple correlation with all other variables.

arguments.name: PROPORTION=
arguments.description: Specifies the proportion of common variance to be accounted for by the retained factors.

arguments.name: RANDOM=
arguments.description: Specifies a positive integer as a starting value for the pseudo-random number generator for use with the option PRIORS=RANDOM.

arguments.name: RCONVERGE=
arguments.description: Specifies the convergence criterion for rotation cycles.

arguments.name: REORDER
arguments.description: Causes the rows (variables) of various factor matrices to be reordered on the output.

arguments.name: RESIDUALS
arguments.description: Displays the residual correlation matrix and the associated partial correlation matrix.

arguments.name: RITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of cycles n for factor rotation.

arguments.name: ROTATE=
arguments.description: Specifies the rotation method. The default is ROTATE=NONE.
arguments.help: ROTATE=BIQUARTIMAX|BIQMAX | EQUAMAX|E | FACTORPARSIMAX|FPA | NONE|N | ORTHCF(p1,p2)|ORCF(p1,p2) | ORTHGENCF(p1,p2,p3,p4)|ORGENCF(p1,p2,p3,p4) | ORTHOMAX<(p)>|ORMAX<(p)> | PARSIMAX|PA | QUARTIMAX|QMAX|Q | VARIMAX|V | BIQUARTIMIN|BIQMIN | COVARIMIN|CVMIN | HK<(p)>|H<(p)> | OBBIQUARTIMAX | OBEQUAMAX|OE | OBFACTORPARSIMAX|OFPA | OBLICF(p1,p2) | OBLIGENCF(p1,p2,p3,p4)|OBGENCF(p1,p2,p3,p4) | OBLIMIN<(p)>|OBMIN<(p)> | OBPARSIMAX|OPA | OBQUARTIMAX|QQMAX | OBVARIMAX|OV | PROCRUSTES | PROMAX<p)>|P<p)> | QUARTIMIN|QMIN

arguments.name: BIQUARTIMAX
arguments.description: Specifies orthogonal biquartimax rotation. This corresponds to the specification ROTATE=ORTHOMAX(.5).

arguments.name: EQUAMAX
arguments.description: Specifies orthogonal equamax rotation. This corresponds to the specification ROTATE=ORTHOMAX with GAMMA=number of factors/2.

arguments.name: FACTORPARSIMAX
arguments.description: Specifies orthogonal factor parsimax rotation. This corresponds to the specification ROTATE=ORTHOMAX with GAMMA=number of variables.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies that no rotation be performed, leaving the original orthogonal solution.

arguments.name: ORTHCF
arguments.description: Specifies the orthogonal Crawford-Ferguson rotation with the weights p1 and p2 for variable parsimony and factor parsimony, respectively.

arguments.name: ORTHGENCF
arguments.description: Specifies the orthogonal generalized Crawford-Ferguson rotation with the four weights p1, p2, p3, and p4.

arguments.name: ORTHOMAX
arguments.description: Specifies the orthomax rotation with orthomax weight p. If ROTATE=ORTHOMAX is used, the default p value is 1 unless specified otherwise in the GAMMA= option.

arguments.name: PARSIMAX
arguments.description: Specifies orthogonal parsimax rotation. This corresponds to the specification ROTATE=ORTHOMAX.

arguments.name: QUARTIMAX
arguments.description: Specifies orthogonal quartimax rotation. This corresponds to the specification ROTATE=ORTHOMAX(0).

arguments.name: VARIMAX
arguments.description: Specifies orthogonal varimax rotation. This corresponds to the specification ROTATE=ORTHOMAX with GAMMA=1.

arguments.name: BIQUARTIMIN
arguments.description: Specifies biquartimin rotation. It corresponds to the specification ROTATE=OBLIMIN(.5) or ROTATE=OBLIMIN with TAU=0.5.

arguments.name: COVARIMIN
arguments.description: Specifies covarimin rotation. It corresponds to the specification ROTATE=OBLIMIN(1) or ROTATE=OBLIMIN with TAU=1.

arguments.name: HK
arguments.description: Specifies Harris-Kaiser case II orthoblique rotation.

arguments.name: OBBIQUARTIMAX
arguments.description: Specifies oblique biquartimax rotation.

arguments.name: OBEQUAMAX
arguments.description: Specifies oblique equamax rotation.

arguments.name: OBFACTORPARSIMAX
arguments.description: Specifies oblique factor parsimax rotation.

arguments.name: OBLICF
arguments.description: Specifies the oblique Crawford-Ferguson rotation with the weights p1 and p2 for variable parsimony and factor parsimony, respectively.

arguments.name: OBLIGENCF
arguments.description: Specifies the oblique generalized Crawford-Ferguson rotation with the four weights p1, p2, p3, and p4.

arguments.name: OBLIMIN
arguments.description: Specifies the oblimin rotation with oblimin weight p.

arguments.name: OBPARSIMAX
arguments.description: Specifies oblique parsimax rotation.

arguments.name: OBQUARTIMAX
arguments.description: Specifies oblique quartimax rotation. This is the same as the QUARTIMIN method.

arguments.name: OBVARIMAX
arguments.description: Specifies oblique varimax rotation.

arguments.name: PROCRUSTES
arguments.description: Specifies oblique Procrustes rotation with the target pattern provided by the TARGET= data set.

arguments.name: PROMAX
arguments.description: Specifies oblique promax rotation. You can use the PREROTATE= option to set the desirable prerotation method, orthogonal or oblique.

arguments.name: QUARTIMIN
arguments.description: Specifies quartimin rotation. It is the same as the oblique quartimax method.

arguments.name: ROUND
arguments.description: Prints correlation and loading matrices with entries multiplied by 100 and rounded to the nearest integer.

arguments.name: SCORE
arguments.description: Displays the factor scoring coefficients.

arguments.name: SCREE
arguments.description: Displays a scree plot of the eigenvalues.

arguments.name: SIMPLE
arguments.description: Displays means, standard deviations, and the number of observations.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies the singularity criterion, where 0 < p < 1. The default value is 1E-8.

arguments.name: STDERR
arguments.description: Computes standard errors for various classes of unrotated and rotated solutions under the maximum likelihood estimation.

arguments.name: TARGET=
arguments.description: Specifies an input data set containing the target pattern for Procrustes rotation.

arguments.name: TAU=
arguments.description: Specifies the oblimin weight used with the option ROTATE=OBLIMIN or PREROTATE=OBLIMIN.

arguments.name: ULTRAHEYWOOD
arguments.description: Allows communalities to exceed 1.

arguments.name: VARDEF=
arguments.description: Specifies the divisor to use in the calculation of variances and covariances. The default value is VARDEF=DF.

arguments.name: DF
arguments.description: Degrees of freedom

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Number of observations

arguments.name: WDF
arguments.description: Sum of weights minus one

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: Sum of weights

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: Factors a weighted correlation or covariance matrix. The WEIGHT option can be used only with the METHOD=PRINCIPAL, METHOD=PRINIT, METHOD=ULS, or METHOD=IMAGE option.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: You can specify a BY statement with PROC FACTOR to obtain separate analyses on observations in groups that are defined by the BY variables. When a BY statement appears, the procedure expects the input data set to be sorted in order of the BY variables. If you specify more than one BY statement, only the last one specified is used.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: If a variable in the data set represents the frequency of occurrence for the other values in the observation, include the variable’s name in a FREQ statement. The procedure then treats the data set as if each observation appears n times, where n is the value of the FREQ variable for the observation. The total number of observations is considered to be equal to the sum of the FREQ variable when the procedure determines degrees of freedom for significance probabilities. If the value of the FREQ variable is missing or is less than one, the observation is not used in the analysis. If the value is not an integer, the value is truncated to an integer. The WEIGHT and FREQ statements have a similar effect, except in determining the number of observations for significance tests.

statements.name: PARTIAL
statements.description: If you want the analysis to be based on a partial correlation or covariance matrix, use the PARTIAL statement to list the variables used to partial out the variables in the analysis.

statements.name: PRIORS
statements.description: The PRIORS statement specifies numeric values between 0.0 and 1.0 for the prior communality estimates for each variable. The first numeric value corresponds to the first variable in the VAR statement, the second value to the second variable, and so on. The number of numeric values must equal the number of variables.

statements.name: VAR
statements.description: VAR variable(s); The VAR statement specifies the numeric variables to be analyzed. If the VAR statement is omitted, all numeric variables not specified in other statements are analyzed.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: If you want to use relative weights for each observation in the input data set, specify a variable containing weights in a WEIGHT statement. This is often done when the variance associated with each observation is different and the values of the weight variable are proportional to the reciprocals of the variances. If a variable value is negative or is missing, it is excluded from the analysis.
